### **How free does Germany want to be?**

Against the backdrop of current global political developments, the topic of freedom is more relevant than ever. What is the significance of freedom for people in Germany today, which is considered one of the freest countries in the world? Is the topic of freedom just a buzzword, especially before the federal elections? What do people understand by it today? Which areas are important to them when it comes to freedom? What is the relationship between security and freedom? And what personal degrees of freedom are important?

In a previously unique study, consisting of an in-depth psychological and statistically representative survey, the [rheingold salon](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/salon-rheingold/) commissioned by [Direktbank Barclaycard Deutschland (now Barclays)](https://www.barclays.de/) initially "put on the couch" 44 people in two- to four-hour in-depth interviews or group discussions. A freedom election compass was developed, and the results were checked representatively with more than 1,000 women and men.

The results: Germans feel free - too free, because freedom scares them. They are willing to exchange their 'great freedom' such as freedom of choice for the small, personal one. A not insignificant part would also sell their freedom. Men more than women. The price is between 1,000,000 and 10,000,000 euros. Nevertheless, in the end, freedom is more important to them than security.

The key results of the study:

### **1. Germans feel free - too free.**

* **Men feel freer than women. Only 2.9% of those surveyed believe that women are freer than men**
* **54.7% believe that too few limits are set in Germany**
* **77% of Germans want stricter enforcement of the laws**

Germans generally feel free. Especially in comparison to other countries, they mainly refer to the fact that one can move freely and think freely. The oldest people in retirement feel the freest. While 86% of them speak of freedom, it is only around 62% among the 30-45 year olds. Men feel much freer at 73% than women at only 64%. Only 2.9% of people believe that women are freer than men.

If you look further behind the scenes, you quickly learn that too much freedom scares people. They want borders, laws and rules. Limitlessness endangers freedom.
If everything is tolerated and everything is taken into account, you end up paying with freedom. Or, to put it another way: after completely free, you quickly become 'unfree'.

*"Well, to be honest, someone only needs to come along and feel attacked as a vegan when a children's song says 'Fox, you stole the goose' - we are simply too tolerant,"* said one participant in the study.

Accordingly, more than 77% of Germans want stricter enforcement of laws, and almost 55% think that there are generally too few limits in Germany.

Furthermore, the existing rules and laws seem far too flexible and not irreversible enough to the Germans. But that means:
The limitations and rules do not have to be sensible in every respect. **They can even be arbitrary.** The crucial thing is that they are irreversible.

*"You can't have understanding for everything, that ultimately contradicts democracy - there must be firm rules in democracy,"* said one quote from the survey.

In order to maintain freedom, paradoxically, intolerance, limits and firm rules are needed. Or: We feel very comfortable in freedom when we are intolerant.

Overall, more than half of those surveyed find that too much consideration is given to foreigners, immigrants and violent offenders. Almost 50% also see it that way with people of other faiths - i.e. non-Christians. Even the needy in society are already being given too much consideration in people's eyes: around 15% each think this about the disabled, single parents, sexual minorities, and the homeless.

### **2. Seek small freedom, offer great freedom**

* **Almost a quarter of all respondents (23.4%) would be willing to completely forego their right to vote in exchange for a payment of 10 million euros**
* **While only 5.2% would be willing to have their partner chosen by their parents for one million euros, 16.2% are willing to completely forego their right to vote for the same price**

The surveys showed that people see freedom not as a common good, but as a very personal one. A strong distinction is made between the large, general freedoms such as freedom of choice, democracy or freedom of the press and the own, small, personal freedoms such as free choice of partner, freedom of clothing or freedom of expression in private circles.

Only here does it really become meaningful for people. They are not willing to accept restrictions on a personal level. What is more:
They are even willing to restrict the freedoms of others if this spares them such restrictions themselves.

For example, almost 40% of those surveyed believe that freedom of the press is not as important as their own personal security. People present themselves as advocates of freedom of the press and expression. But if this means having to restrict themselves personally as a consequence, then they prefer to see the press censored.

For example, the possibility of buying cheap fashion from large, international textile chains means freedom and is more important than the freedom of children producing in other countries. In addition, the respondents found it perfectly acceptable that they themselves pay lower contributions to health insurance companies or insurance companies than fat people, smokers or people living unhealthy lives. This seemed fairer to them than a solidary and democratic redistribution.

It quickly became clear in the interviews that people strongly divide freedom into two areas - their own, personal "small freedom" and the "great freedom".

### **3. The price of freedom - a "deal" at the expense of others**

* **Almost one in four (22.2%) would accept that others have to restrict themselves in order to be free themselves**
* **54% believe that freedom is not free**

Following Trump's maxim, freedom is treated like a "deal". Ultimately, freedom is always a business for people for which they have to pay a price. Freedom is not free - 54% of all respondents think so. It requires security as a basis to feel free, such as controls at the airport or increased video surveillance.

Shopping as cheaply as possible yourself only comes at the expense of the environment in other countries or at the expense of children.

People themselves would prefer to always get away 'cheaply' - but the others should pay the restrictions / the price. This is also shown by these quotes from the qualitative survey:

*"Let's put it this way: if I could ensure that my children can move freely and travel and the price would be that I would have to stay at home forever, then I would do that."*

In a survey experiment in the in-depth psychological interviews, it could be clearly shown how far people would go. When asked whom the people of Leipzig/Cologne/Hamburg would lock up for their own freedom, an ever same pattern could be seen:

*The Bavarians? Yes.*
*The rest of the Germans? Yes.*
*Certain religious groups? Yes.*
*Only with the people of Leipzig/Hamburg/Cologne themselves was it over.*

And most of them did not even notice the same principle. People only think of their own advantage in the short term. "Freedom begins where I restrict the freedom of others" seems to be the new imperative of freedom. Accordingly, 62% of those up to 30 years old accept that children in developing countries pay the price for their cheap clothing.

The fact that freedom is not free and someone has to pay the price is found by 54% of all respondents and 57% of men.

Nevertheless: People do not sacrifice freedom to security. 96.4% find freedom important. Security comes with 95% to a slightly lower value.

### 4. **Freedom needs community**

* **79.6% consider friends to be a crucial aspect of felt freedom**

* **In comparison, the state (37%) or church (20.3%) are not necessarily perceived as freedom-enhancing**

People need friends, love and community in order to be able to feel freedom at all. When asked which aspects promote freedom, friends (79.6%), family (70.6%) and their own partner (67.4%) were mentioned most frequently. The close bond to social contacts gives security in the world perceived as insecure. *"Being completely free also means that you are completely alone, you don't want that, you want to belong and be popular"*, describes a test person from the study. In contrast, church, state or even the job are perceived more as control instances and freedom limiters.

Freedom also becomes noticeable through its enemy images and when it has to be defended against supposed enemies: Muslims, refugees, rulers, "dictators" of other states. Especially in the demarcation from enemy images, a kind of protective wall can be erected against the enemies of one's own freedom: *"We have more freedoms, travel opportunities, free choice of clothing than others,"* said one participant in the study.

From a psychological point of view, the idea of Trump's wall is also a freedom wall. Almost all respondents build such a protective wall in their heads. Many also want a real wall against 'enemies' (refugees) in the concrete situation - especially in Bavaria.

However, this wall in the heads is of a magical nature, it is quasi-semipermeable. It shields off without restricting one's own travel or movement possibilities.

People have to demarcate their freedom from enemies - they cannot endure limitless freedom. At the same time, they need friends, love and community in order to be able to feel freedom at all.

Or as one respondent puts it: *"On Facebook, I don't always say what I think because I just don't want to lose so many friends - you want harmony in order to feel free."*

### 5. **Thoughts are limitlessly free - really?**

It is difficult for many people to free themselves completely from constraints in their minds, to do nothing with a good conscience. They almost always feel driven. Nevertheless, the longing is great to want to be completely purposeless, immersed, "lazy". *"I just like to sleep, but you're not allowed to admit that,"* said one participant in the study. This makes it clear what problem people in Germany have with freedom today. Doing nothing quickly appears threatening, unproductive, is a reason for a bad conscience. Even in their heads, people are hardly ever really free.

For almost all people, childhood is the ideal of freedom: completely immersed in the game, forgetting space and time, within a fixed framework that the parents give (time of being at home etc.) and being safe in a loving community.

No thoughts had to be given to the limits of freedom, the enemies and friends. They were set 'arbitrarily' by the parents. Thus, childhood fulfills the most important criteria of freedom:
Clear rules and 'arbitrary' restrictions, being safe in the community as well as complete immersion and mentally imaginative freedom.

### 6. **The Freedom Choice-O-Mat**

Over 1,000 people finally chose which freedoms are important to them:

![](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Freiheit-1024x929.png)

If only one freedom could be selected among different freedoms, only 1.2% of those surveyed chose freedom of choice as the most important freedom and only 1.6% freedom of the press. On closer inspection, freedom of the press and freedom of choice are sacrificed to personal freedoms. Personal freedoms such as free choice of partner are more important to people. But also the apparently most important freedom of opinion is 'for sale'. With the help of the Freedom Choice-O-Mat, participants were asked for what amount they would have which freedom bought off. The results show that 'freedom' is indeed for sale. For example, around 34% are willing to sell freedom of expression for 10 million euros, as long as they are still allowed to say their opinion in private.

Other freedoms are sold even faster and sooner. Almost 24% would sell the right to vote completely for 10 million euros - if they were allowed to vote one last time, even 32%.

Partner choice is mainly bought off by men, if they were allowed to take a short look at the partner beforehand (almost 20%). 60% would have the right to free choice of clothing bought off for 1 million euros.

According to people, freedom is particularly favored by certain things or institutions. Neither the church nor the state or society in general play a role in this. Especially among younger people, family (82%) and friends (89%) are seen as the greatest givers of freedom.

Younger people are willing to forego a car (around 50%) for the rest of their lives, older people are more likely to forego a smartphone (around 51%). The car is mainly becoming a freedom runner among the 45 + generation.

**Facts about the study**

The findings on the topic of freedom have come about through neutral, product-independent surveys. They were in no way influenced by product questions and are not used for product-related market research.

* As part of the qualitative survey, group discussions and individual in-depth interviews were conducted in Cologne, Hamburg, Leipzig and Munich. 22 women and 22 men aged 18 to 65 took part. The theoretical-scientific foundation is based on morphological psychology, developed by Prof. Wilhelm Salber, University of Cologne.

* For the representative, quantitative survey, more than 1,000 people aged 18 to 65 were subsequently surveyed from the online access panel

* The surveys were conducted in a period from February to June 2017.

[Wie kreiert man WOW-Erlebnisse beim Einkauf?](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/marktforschung-services/)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**WOW-Erlebnisse beim Einkauf führen dazu, dass Kunden wiederkommen. Und sie tragen in hohem Umfang zu einer höheren Weiterempfehlungsrate bei.**

Einkaufen wird für uns erst dann faszinierend, wenn es nicht nur um eine nüchterne Einkaufsliste geht. Beim Einkaufen wollen wir überrascht werden, etwas erleben, uns verlieben, uns verzaubern lassen \
– kurz: Wir wollen WOW-Erlebnisse haben.

### Wie lassen sich WOW-Erlebnisse systematisch herstellen?

Was als ein WOW-Erlebnis empfunden wird, ist abhängig von Situationen, Umfeldern und Vorlieben. Exemplarisch finden Sie hier Kurzbeschreibungen von zwei psychologischen Produkttypen aus unseren systematischen Analysen. Wir haben die Darstellung dabei mit Märchen in Austausch gebracht, weil sich die psychologische ‚Mechanik‘ der Typen so gut illustrieren lässt.

### Beispiel: Luxus-Artikel – Des Kaisers neue Kleider

Käufer von Luxusprodukten und Luxusmarken haben häufig die Sorge, dass ihre heißbegehrten Luxusartikel vielleicht in Wirklichkeit doch nicht so viel wert sind und die stolzen Luxus-Preise am Ende nicht gerechtfertigt sind. Es ist wie im Märchen ‚des Kaisers neue Kleider‘: Es bleibt eine Rest-Sorge, auf clevere Betrüger hereinzufallen, die nur vorgeben, sensationelle neue Luxusprodukte und -kleider herzustellen. Wie lässt sich aber das Gegenteil beweisen?

Paradoxerweise lässt sich diese Sorge nur ausräumen, wenn gerade die Käufer von Luxusprodukten etwas umsonst bekommen. Wenn der Verkäufer des Anzuges von einem Luxushersteller auch nach 1½ Jahren das gute Stück anstandslos zurücknimmt und ersetzt, weil eine Naht aufgegangen ist, dann beschert er dem Luxus-Käufer ein WOW-Erlebnis. Denn der Händler zeigt ihm, dass er selbst auch die hohen Erwartungen an das Luxusprodukt hat und dass ein entsprechender Service für diesen Luxusartikel selbstverständlich ist. Der Käufer wird wiederkommen und anderen von dem tollen Service berichten. Ähnliches gilt für die Pflege von hoch wertigem Schmuck und Uhren. Serviceleistungen und Einladungen vom Juwelier, die nicht berechnet werden, „beweisen“ psychologisch paradoxerweise den Wert der Objekte, gerade weil sie nicht berechnet werden.

### Beispiel: Mainstream-Outfit – Goldmarie & Pechmarie

Käuferinnen und Käufer von Mainstreamprodukten suchen oft Sicherheit, wenn sie sich am „Gängigen“ orientieren. Sie wollen wie die Goldmarie im Märchen nichts falsch machen und die Erwartungen erfüllen. Denn sie haben Sorge, dass sie ansonsten wie die Pechmarie geächtet werden, wenn sie sich nicht um die Normen, Erwartungen und Wünsche der anderen kümmern.

Auch wenn sich diese Käuferinnen und Käufer oft angepasst und ‚pflegeleicht‘ geben, haben sie dennoch anspruchsvolle Wünsche: Denn sie wollen für ihr angepasstes Verhalten belohnt werden. Sich anzupassen soll sich auszahlen, wie bei der Goldmarie, die am Ende im Märchen für ihr Verhalten mit Gold überschüttet wird.

WOW-Erlebnisse stellen sich für diese Käufer-Klientel von Mainstream-Outfit daher häufig gerade dann ein, wenn ihr ein ganz besonderes individualisiertes Einkauferlebnis geboten wird. Das kann auf ganz verschiedenen Wegen hergestellt werden – hier einige Beispiele: „Pröbchen“, die besonders schön eingepackt sind, Schuhe oder Kleider, die der Händler gerade für diese Person persönlich zurückgelegt hat; individualisierte Rabatte. Mit wenigen richtig eingesetzten individuellen Belohnungen lassen sich so tolle WOW-Erlebnisse herstellen.

Die Psychologie der Kontexte analysieren und WOW-Erlebnisse kreieren!
---------------------------------------------------------------------

Es gibt es viele weitere psychologische Bereiche: Status-Produkte zum Repräsentieren, Lingerie-Produkte fürs private Intime, Baby-Produkte fürs Mama- und Papa-Sein. Kennt man die Psycho-Logik der Käufer in diesen Bereichen, lassen sich Kauferlebnisse systematisch und gezielt herstellen.

[How to create WOW experiences while shopping?](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/marktforschung-services/)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**WOW experiences while shopping lead to customers returning. And they contribute to a higher recommendation rate to a great extent.**

Shopping only becomes fascinating for us when it's not just about a sober shopping list. When shopping, we want to be surprised, experience something, fall in love, be enchanted \
– in short: We want to have WOW experiences.

### How can WOW experiences be systematically created?

What is perceived as a WOW experience depends on situations, environments and preferences. As an example, you will find brief descriptions of two psychological product types from our systematic analyses. We have exchanged the presentation with fairy tales because the psychological 'mechanics' of the types can be illustrated so well.

### Example: Luxury items – The Emperor's New Clothes

Buyers of luxury products and luxury brands are often concerned that their coveted luxury items may not actually be worth that much and that the proud luxury prices are not justified in the end. It is like in the fairy tale 'The Emperor's New Clothes': There remains a residual concern about falling for clever fraudsters who only pretend to manufacture sensational new luxury products and clothes. But how can the opposite be proven?

Paradoxically, this concern can only be dispelled if buyers of luxury products get something for free. If the seller of the suit from a luxury manufacturer takes back and replaces the good piece without complaint even after 1½ years because a seam has come undone, then he gives the luxury buyer a WOW experience. Because the dealer shows him that he himself also has high expectations of the luxury product and that a corresponding service is a matter of course for this luxury item. The buyer will come back and tell others about the great service. The same applies to the care of high-quality jewelry and watches. Services and invitations from the jeweler that are not charged "prove" psychologically paradoxically the value of the objects, precisely because they are not charged.

### Example: Mainstream Outfit – Goldmarie & Pechmarie

Buyers of mainstream products often seek security when they orientate themselves towards what is “common”. Like Goldmarie in the fairy tale, they don't want to do anything wrong and meet expectations. Because they are worried that they will otherwise be ostracized like Pechmarie if they do not take care of the norms, expectations and wishes of others.

Even if these buyers often appear adapted and 'easy to care for', they still have demanding wishes: because they want to be rewarded for their adapted behavior. Adapting should pay off, like Goldmarie, who is showered with gold in the end in the fairy tale for her behavior.

WOW experiences for this buyer clientele of mainstream outfits therefore often arise precisely when they are offered a very special, individualized shopping experience. This can be produced in a variety of ways – here are a few examples: “samples” that are particularly nicely packaged, shoes or clothes that the dealer has set aside specifically for this person; individualized discounts. With a few correctly used individual rewards, great WOW experiences can be created.

Analyze the psychology of the contexts and create WOW experiences!
---------------------------------------------------------------------

There are many other psychological areas: status products for representing, lingerie products for private intimacy, baby products for being a mom and dad. If you know the psycho-logic of the buyers in these areas, shopping experiences can be created systematically and in a targeted manner.

titleDe: Jugend ungeschminkt
titleEn: Youth unvarnished
author: lönneker & imdahl rheingold salon
contentDe:
**Selbstbild & Selbstwert von Jugendlichen**

#### *Eine tiefenpsychologisch-repräsentative Studie von rheingold salon im Auftrag des [IKW — Industrieverband Körperpflege- und Waschmittel e. V.](https://www.ikw.org/schoenheitspflege)*

Es gibt eine Vielzahl von Jugendstudien, die sich mit den Werten, den Vorlieben oder auch dem Medienverhalten beschäftigen. Dabei wird das Thema Erwachsenwerden selbst eher weniger behandelt. Welche Sorgen und Nöte sind damit verbunden, ein Mann oder eine Frau zu werden? Wie gehen die Jugendlichen mit den typischen Gefühlsschwankungen in der Pubertät oder der aufkeimenden Sexualität um? Wie entwickeln sie ein positives Gefühl zu sich selbst und Selbstsicherheit in ihrer Wirkung auf andere?

Die Entwicklung des Selbstwertgefühls in dieser turbulenten Zeit ist der Forschungsschwerpunkt der vorliegenden tiefenpsychologisch-repräsentativen Studie mit Jugendlichen und jungen Erwachsenen im Alter von 14 bis 21 Jahren, die rheingold salon im Auftrag des Industrieverbands Körperpflege- und Waschmittel durchgeführt hat. Nicht allein, welche Werte die Jugendlichen haben, sondern warum sie diese haben und wie sie entstehen, hat uns interessiert. Und welche Rolle der Körper beziehungsweise das Aussehen dabei spielt. Welchen Einfluss hat die Pflege des Äußeren auf das Selbstwertgefühl, wenn es innen brodelt? Können Kosmetik- und Schönheitsprodukte die Jugendlichen bei ihrer Selbstfindung unterstützen?

Die Ergebnisse der tiefenpsychologischen Studie zeigen die Jugendlichen ungeschminkt – auch mit den Seiten, die junge Menschen nur allzu gern verstecken

[**Lesen Sie hier mehr…**](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Jugend-ungeschminkt.pdf)

**Die Studie kann hier** \
**als Vortrag gebucht werden.**

**Fakten zur Studie:**\
Die Erkenntnisse zum Thema „Jugend und Kosmetik“ sind durch neutrale, produktunabhängige Befragungen zustande gekommen. Sie wurden in keiner Weise durch Produktfragen beeinflusst und dienen auch nicht der produktbezogenen Marktforschung.

* Im Rahmen der qualitativen Befragung wurden Gruppendiskussionen und Einzel-Tiefeninterviews in Köln, Hamburg, Dresden und München durchgeführt. Insgesamt nahmen 56 Jungen und Mädchen im Alter von 14 bis 21 Jahren teil.
* Für die repräsentative quantitative Befragung wurden anschließend mehr als 1.000 Personen in einem Online-Panel befragt. Insgesamt nahmen 511 Mädchen und 501 Jungen im Alter von 14 bis 21 Jahren an der Befragung teil
contentEn:
**Self-image & self-esteem of adolescents**

#### *A depth psychological-representative study by rheingold salon commissioned by [IKW — Industrieverband Körperpflege- und Waschmittel e. V.](https://www.ikw.org/schoenheitspflege)*

There are a large number of youth studies that deal with values, preferences or media behavior. The topic of growing up itself is less addressed. What worries and hardships are associated with becoming a man or a woman? How do young people deal with the typical mood swings in puberty or budding sexuality? How do you develop a positive feeling about yourself and self-confidence in your effect on others?

The development of self-esteem in this turbulent time is the research focus of the present depth psychological-representative study with adolescents and young adults aged 14 to 21, which rheingold salon has carried out on behalf of the Industrieverband Körperpflege- und Waschmittel. We were interested not only in what values young people have, but why they have them and how they arise. And what role does the body or appearance play? What influence does the care of the exterior have on self-esteem when it is simmering inside? Can cosmetic and beauty products help young people find themselves?

The results of the depth psychological study show the adolescents unvarnished – also with the sides that young people like to hide all too much

[**Read more here…**](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Jugend-ungeschminkt.pdf)

**The study can be booked here** \
**as a lecture.**

**Facts about the study:**\\
The findings on the topic of “youth and cosmetics” came about through neutral, product-independent surveys. They were in no way influenced by product questions and are not used for product-related market research.

* As part of the qualitative survey, group discussions and individual in-depth interviews were conducted in Cologne, Hamburg, Dresden and Munich. A total of 56 boys and girls aged 14 to 21 took part.
* For the representative quantitative survey, more than 1,000 people were then surveyed in an online panel. A total of 511 girls and 501 boys aged 14 to 21 took part in the survey

titleDe: „Kommt der Pranger zurück?“
titleEn: „Is the pillory coming back?“
author: Jens Lönneker
contentDe:
So betitelte die „Wetzlarer Neue Zeitung“ in der Serie „Demokratie leben!“ das Interview mit [Jens Lönneker](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/gruender-team/) zum Thema Glaubwürdigkeit. Die Frage ist: Wenn Emotionen zu Wahrheit werden, ist dann die Demokratie in Gefahr? Und wer ist verantwortlich für diese Entwicklungen? Die Politiker, die Presse, die Journalisten? Lesen Sie das Interview zu unserem Thema „Pröffentlichkeit“ oder wenn Privates und Öffentliches zusammenfallen.

### **Wer Tränen zeigt, wird oft für glaubwürdiger gehalten, als jemand, der mit Fakten aufwartet. Doch wenn Emotionen zur Wahrheit werden, gerät dann die Demokratie in Gefahr? Nicht unbedingt, findet [Jens Lönneker](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/gruender-team/), Geschäftsführer von rheingold salon.**

**Iris Baar:** Herr Lönneker, selbstgebastelte Galgen für Politiker, „Lügenpresse“-Rufe auf Demonstrationen. Was haben Politiker und Journalisten falsch gemacht, dass sie so an Glaubwürdigkeit verloren haben?

**Jens Lönneker:** Ich sehe die Verantwortlichkeit nicht bei den beiden Berufsständen direkt. Sie sind Opfer einer gesellschaftlichen und kulturellen Entwicklung, die heute Formen der Argumentationen im öffentlichen Raumzulässt, die vor 50 oder 60 Jahren nicht zulässig waren. Dazu zählen–wenn man es noch freundlich ausdrücken will –die emotionalen Äußerungen, aber auch Dinge, die wir schon glaubten, überwunden zu haben wie beispielsweise den Pranger. Den haben wir heute wieder, in dem Menschen beschimpft und verunglimpft werden bis hin zu den Plakaten mit Politikern am Galgen. Diese heftige Form der Auseinandersetzung, der Beschimpfungen, des Shit Storms aus der Anonymität der Masse heraus, das ist neu. Oder seit dem Mittelalter wieder da.

**Iris Baar:** Was hat sich in den vergangenen 50 Jahren in unserer Gesellschaft verändert, dass emotionalen Äußerungen bis hin zu derartigen Entgleisungen mehr Glaubwürdigkeit geschenkt wird als nüchternen Fakten?

**Jens Lönneker:** Glaubwürdig ist heute jemand, der emotional wird. Das Argumentieren auf Basis von Fakten wird dagegen als reines Taktieren empfunden. Woher das kommt? Die Trennung zwischen privatem und öffentlichem Raum, die wir über lange Zeit in den westlichen Ländern hatten, existiert nicht mehr. Lange Zeit musste man in Ländern der so genannten Aufklärung und im westlichen Raum in der Öffentlichkeit vernünftig und rational aufgeklärt argumentieren. Das ist in den vergangenen Jahren immer weiter in den Hintergrund gedrängt worden. Äußerungen, die bisher im privaten Bereich zulässig waren, emotionale und in sich widersprüchliche Argumentationen, wurden dafür mehr und mehr im öffentlichen Raum zugelassen. Wir sprechen in einer unserer Studien in diesem Zusammenhang von der neuen Pröffentlichkeit, also das Private und das Öffentliche fallen zusammen.

**Iris Baar:** Was bedeutet das für unsere Demokratie?

**Jens Lönneker:** Diese Pröffentlichkeit bringt uns in eine Situation, die für Politiker und Journalisten unglücklich, ja sehr unangenehm ist. Klassische und vernünftige Darstellungsformen werden zum einen als nicht authentisch und nicht wahrhaftig diskreditiert. Zugleich bekommen Politiker oder auch Journalisten nur noch dann eine gewisse Reichweite, also Gehör, wenn sie selbst stärker zu Mitteln greifen, die nicht vernünftig sind. Wenn sie sich also auch emotionaler Bilder bedienen. Darin besteht die Gefahr.

**Iris Baar:** Das Glaubwürdigkeitsproblem hat populistische Bewegungen wie Pegida hervorgebracht, auch die am rechten Rand angesiedelte AfD profitiert von dem Phänomen. Rückt unser Land durch die „Privatisierung des Öffentlichen“ beziehungsweise den Sieg der Emotionen über die Faktennach rechts?

**Jens Lönneker:** Im Moment ist das so. Das könnte aber auch nach links gehen. In den westlichen Kulturen, also nicht nur in Deutschland, haben wir das Problem, dass die Menschen in den vergangenen Jahrzehnten zwischen den rechten und den linken Führungseliten vergessen worden sind. Die rechten Eliten haben die Grenzen immer weiter aufgemacht, indem sie die Privatisierung der Märkte vorangetrieben haben. Die linken Eliten haben die Internationalisierung besungen und Multi-Kulti propagiert. Was dabei vergessen wurde, ist der Teil der Leute, die da nicht mitkommen .Die jetzt fragen: Wo bleiben wir denn? Das sind die Menschen, die jetzt anfangen, zu protestieren. Sie sind tendenziell älter und ihren Geburtsländern verhaftet. Es sind die, die einen Donald Trump, die AfD oder einen Brexit wählen.

**Iris Baar:** Das gilt aber nicht für alle westlichen Kulturen…

**Jens Lönneker:** Nein, es kann auch ganz woanders hinführen, wie wir in Frankreich am Beispiel Macron sehen können. Ihm ist es gelungen, den Menschen ein ganz neues Angebot zu machen, das parteienübergreifend ist und dadurch verschiedene Klientel bedienen kann, auch die nationalistischen Kräfte. Ohne Macron hätte die nationalistische Partei Le Pen deutlich mehr Stimmen bekommen.

**Iris Baar:** Macron ist also Hoffnungsträger für den Erhalt demokratischer Strukturen im Westen?

**Jens Lönneker:** Kann man so sagen. Macron ist es gelungen, Politik ein Stückweit zu revolutionieren. Er ist unverbraucht, versucht, neue Strukturen aufzubauen und das Land zu modernisieren. Er versucht, einen Bogen zu spannen, der links und rechts überwindet. Am Ende ist das so eine Art Heilands Versprechen. Man muss sehen, was sich davon im Alltag umsetzen lässt. Bei Obama ist ja vieles im alltäglichen Politik-Geschäft zerrieben worden. Aber im Moment ruhen auf Macron viele Hoffnungen.

**Iris Baar:** Was können Politiker oder Journalisten hierzulande tun, um Glaubwürdigkeit wieder herzustellen?

**Jens Lönneker:** Ich denke, dass wir die Zeit nicht zurückdrehen können .Wir müssen damit leben, dass wir heute in einem pröffentlichen Raum unterwegs sind, der die privat-persönlichen Momente mit einbindet. Der homo oeconomicus, der Mensch, der wirtschaftliche Entscheidungen nur nach rein rationalen Erwägungen trifft, ist ein Auslaufmodell. Wir müssen uns damit beschäftigen, wie wir die Emotionen, die ja doch irgendwie wichtig sind, integriert bekommen. Politiker sollten deshalb den Mut haben, Persönlichkeitsmerkmale mit einzubringen, Ecken und Kanten zu zeigen. Was die Medien anbelangt, können –gerade im politischen Bereich – durchaus mehr Elemente aus dem Bereich der Homestory in die Berichterstattung einfließen. Und Lokalzeitungen müssen über Themen eine Identifikation der Leser mit ihrer Region schaffen. Wir müssen nur aufpassen, dass Emotionalität nicht alleine die neue Währung wird. Wir müssen auf eine gesunde Mischung zwischen öffentlich-rational vernünftigen Argumentationen und den emotional-privaten Äußerungen hinarbeiten.

[**Lesen Sie hier den Artikel der „Wetzlaurer Neue Zeitung“…**](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Zeitungsgruppe-lahndill_20170629_demokratie_loumlnneker.pdf)

\*mit freundlicher Genehmigung der Zeitungsgruppe [LahnDill](https://www.allgemeine-zeitung.de/tag/lahn-dill-kreis)
contentEn:
So headlined the "Wetzlarer Neue Zeitung" in the series "Living Democracy!" the interview with [Jens Lönneker](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/gruender-team/) on the subject of credibility. The question is: If emotions become truth, is democracy in danger? And who is responsible for these developments? The politicians, the press, the journalists? Read the interview on our topic "Pröfffentlichkeit" or when private and public coincide.

### **Anyone who shows tears is often considered more credible than someone who comes up with facts. But if emotions become truth, is democracy in danger? Not necessarily, says [Jens Lönneker](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/gruender-team/), Managing Director of rheingold salon.**

**Iris Baar:** Mr. Lönneker, homemade gallows for politicians, "lying press" calls at demonstrations. What have politicians and journalists done wrong that they have lost so much credibility?

**Jens Lönneker:** I do not see the responsibility with the two professions directly. They are victims of a social and cultural development that today allows forms of argumentation in public space that were not permissible 50 or 60 years ago. These include - if you want to put it kindly - emotional utterances, but also things that we already thought we had overcome, such as the pillory. We have that again today, in that people are insulted and denigrated, up to the posters with politicians on the gallows. This violent form of confrontation, of insults, of shit storms from the anonymity of the masses, is new. Or back again since the Middle Ages.

**Iris Baar:** What has changed in our society in the past 50 years that emotional utterances, including such derailments, are given more credibility than sober facts?

**Jens Lönneker:** Today, someone who becomes emotional is credible. Arguing on the basis of facts, on the other hand, is perceived as pure tactics. Where does this come from? The separation between private and public space, which we had for a long time in Western countries, no longer exists. For a long time, in countries of the so-called Enlightenment and in the Western world, one had to argue rationally and rationally in public. In recent years, this has been increasingly pushed into the background. Utterances that were previously permissible in the private sphere, emotional and internally contradictory arguments, have been increasingly permitted in the public sphere. In one of our studies, we speak in this context of the new Pröfffentlichkeit, i.e. the private and the public coincide.

**Iris Baar:** What does this mean for our democracy?

**Jens Lönneker:** This Pröfffentlichkeit puts us in a situation that is unfortunate, indeed very unpleasant, for politicians and journalists. Classical and reasonable forms of presentation are discredited on the one hand as not authentic and not truthful. At the same time, politicians or journalists only get a certain reach, i.e. a hearing, if they themselves resort more to means that are not reasonable. If they also use more emotional images. That is the danger.

**Iris Baar:** The credibility problem has spawned populist movements such as Pegida, and the AfD, which is based on the right, is also benefiting from the phenomenon. Is our country moving to the right through the "privatization of the public" or the victory of emotions over facts?

**Jens Lönneker:** At the moment it is. But it could also go to the left. In Western cultures, i.e. not only in Germany, we have the problem that people have been forgotten between the right and left-wing elites in recent decades. The right-wing elites have opened the borders further and further by pushing ahead with the privatization of the markets. The left-wing elites have sung the praises of internationalization and propagated multi-culti. What has been forgotten in the process is the part of the people who do not come along. They are now asking: Where do we stand? These are the people who are now starting to protest. They tend to be older and attached to their countries of birth. These are the people who vote for a Donald Trump, the AfD or a Brexit.

**Iris Baar:** But this does not apply to all Western cultures...

**Jens Lönneker:** No, it can also lead to something completely different, as we can see in France with the example of Macron. He has succeeded in making a completely new offer to the people, which is cross-party and can therefore serve different clienteles, including the nationalist forces. Without Macron, the nationalist party Le Pen would have received significantly more votes.

**Iris Baar:** So Macron is a beacon of hope for the preservation of democratic structures in the West?

**Jens Lönneker:** You could say that. Macron has succeeded in revolutionizing politics to some extent. He is fresh, trying to build new structures and modernize the country. He is trying to build a bridge that overcomes the left and the right. In the end, it is a kind of Savior's promise. We have to see what can be implemented in everyday life. With Obama, a lot has been ground down in the everyday political business. But at the moment, many hopes rest on Macron.

**Iris Baar:** What can politicians or journalists do in this country to restore credibility?

**Jens Lönneker:** I don't think we can turn back time. We have to live with the fact that we are now in a public space that includes private and personal moments. The homo oeconomicus, the person who makes economic decisions only according to purely rational considerations, is a thing of the past. We have to deal with how we can integrate emotions, which are somehow important. Politicians should therefore have the courage to bring in personality traits, to show edges and corners. As far as the media are concerned, more elements from the field of the homestory can certainly be incorporated into the reporting - especially in the political field. And local newspapers must create an identification of the readers with their region through topics. We just have to be careful that emotionality does not become the new currency alone. We must work towards a healthy mix between public-rational reasonable arguments and emotional-private utterances.

[**Read the article from the "Wetzlaurer Neue Zeitung" here...**](https://www.rheingold-salon.de/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Zeitungsgruppe-lahndill_20170629_demokratie_loumlnneker.pdf)

\*with kind permission of the newspaper group [LahnDill](https://www.allgemeine-zeitung.de/tag/lahn-dill-kreis)
